EmailTemplate.subject: December Spring News: Spring Boot 1.2 introduces new Java EE API support
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
DECEMBER 2014 <http://spring.io/blog/2014/12/11/spring-boot-1-2-0-released> Spring Boot 1.2 introduces new Java EE API support Spring Boot 1.2 GA adds deeper support for key Java EE APIs like JAX-RS, JMS, JTA, JSR330, Servlet 3.1, and for popular open source like Jackson’s JSON processor, RedHat’s undertow web server, and DropWizard’s Metrics library. For all the details, check out Phil Webb’s release blog <http://spring.io/blog/2014/12/11/spring-boot-1-2-0-released> and Josh Long’s blog “Bootiful Java EE support <http://spring.io/blog/2014/11/23/bootiful-java-ee-support-in-spring-boot-1-2>” for example code on how you can make Java EE dramatically more productive. First, Spring decoupled Java EE from the container, and now with Spring Boot, you’re decoupled from even the servlet engine! Lastly, with Spring IO platform we supply a versioned release of the entire platform in the same fashion Java EE does, so you can rest assured. Combine all this with deep Java 8 support and a strong community, and it’s easy to see why the Spring IO Platform is the open source leader in Java development. Learn More <http://spring.io/blog/2014/12/11/spring-boot-1-2-0-released> "Bootiful" Java EE Support in Spring Boot 1.2 Spring Boot 1.2 just released <http://spring.io/blog/2014/12/11/spring-boot-1-2-0-released> and it's packed full of features. This month’s Tech Tip is on this example code and blog <http://spring.io/blog/2014/11/23/bootiful-java-ee-support-in-spring-boot-1-2> where I want to look at - and demonstrate - some of the many new features in Spring Boot 1.2 that make the lives of those coming from, or otherwise building on, Java EE easier. It's worth mentioning that a lot of this support has been possible with Spring before, of course, but now with Spring Boot 1.2, it's just so darned easy! Also, here's an example program that demonstrates Boot's new JAX-RS auto-configuration <http://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/1.2.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT/reference/htmlsingle/#boot-features-jersey> (in this case, using Jersey 2.x <https://jersey.java.net/>) in the GreetingEndpoint. It demonstrates global transactions with the new auto-configured JTA support <http://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/1.2.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT/reference/htmlsingle/#boot-features-jta>. This example also uses the Wildfly (from RedHat) application server's awesome Undertow embedded HTTP server <http://undertow.io/> instead of (the default) Apache Tomcat. Spring Boot now supports Servlet 3.1 by default with Jetty 9, Tomcat 8 and Undertow, while still supporting Servlet 3. This example also uses the new @SpringBootApplication annotation which combines @Configuration, @EnableAutoConfiguration and @ComponentScan. Nice!
There are a slew of new features beyond these. Check out the release notes <https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-1.2-Release-Notes> for the full scoop! Suppress types in content-assist Are you annoyed by java.awt.List showing up in the content-assist when you would like to use the collections library instead? You can avoid that by excluding certain types from showing up in the content-assist via the Preferences -> Java -> Appearance -> Type Filters. You can list concrete types as well as packages - and it helps a lot to clean up the content-assist proposal list. Enjoy! Building Scalable Data Applications with Spring and GemFire Speaker: Luke Shannon
GemFire is Pivotal's distributed In Memory Data grid. In this session we will cover simplifying configuring a GemFire grid using Spring Data GemFire, and explore how data is dynamically distributed and made highly available as the grid resources are increased or decreased to meet increased client demand. GemFire access and testing patterns using Spring will be reviewed in detail.
We will walk through creating a domain object and using Spring Data GemFire Repositories to perform CRUD operations on a GemFire grid, creating a Spring MVC/Spring Boot application that uses GemFire as its persistence layer, review how Spring Boot and Spring Data GemFire can be used to help with GemFire test cases and how Spring Data GemFire can make creation and execution of GemFire functions easier. We will also explore how Spring XD can be used to load and monitor data changes in the grid. This will be a hands on, code oriented session. Europe Tuesday, January 13, 2015 3:00PM GMT Time (London, GMT) Register <http://connect.pivotal.io/OSS_Webinar_7AMBuildingScalableDataApplicationswithSpringandGemFire_Register.html> North America Tuesday, January 13, 2015 10:00AM PST (San Francisco, GMT-08:00) Register <http://connect.pivotal.io/OSS_Webinar_10AMBuildingScalableDataApplicationswithSpringandGemFire_Register.html> Introducing the Java DSL for Spring Integration Speaker: Gary Russell
The Spring Integration JavaConfig and DSL extension provides a set of convenient Builders and a fluent API to configure Spring Integration message flows from Spring @Configuration classes. The Java DSL for Spring Integration is essentially a facade for Spring Integration. The DSL provides a simple way to embed Spring Integration Message Flows into your application using the fluent Builder pattern together with existing Java and Annotation configurations from Spring Framework and Spring Integration as well. Another useful tool to simplify configuration is Java 8 Lambdas.
Developers joining this webinar will learn the DSL basics and see it in action.
